p: AAV‐NP immunization induced a remarkably broad antibody response covering all tested influenza viruses and capable to activate FcγR, despite the fact that NP is considered a major stimulus of cytotoxic T‐cell immunity (Sipo et al, 2011). Previous studies suggested a protective capacity of NP‐specific FcγR‐activating antibodies (Vanderven et al, 2016). However, the exact mechanism remains unclear, since these antibodies target a viral antigen supposedly localized in the interior of the virion or host cell (Bodewes et al, 2013). Besides ADCC induction, FcγR regulates innate and adaptive immunity, including antibody responses themselves by regulation of B‐cell selection, maturation, and survival (Bournazos & Ravetch, 2017). The finding that AAV‐NP induced antibodies potently activated the murine inhibitory FcγRIIB might suggest rather a regulatory role of these antibodies. However, both humoral and cellular immunity will likely contribute to NP‐mediated protection. Further experiments are needed to extend knowledge on involved protective mechanisms (Carragher et al, 2008; Mullarkey et al, 2016; He et al, 2017).
